dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Welcome back to the podcast! So, we're always talking about, you know, the climate crisis, all the doom and gloom, the rising GHGs, which, uh, are still increasing faster than anticipated, by the way.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Welcome back to the podcast! So, we're always talking about, you know, the climate crisis, all the doom and gloom, the rising G H Gs, which, uh, are still increasing faster than anticipated, by the way.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Despite the existential threat posed by rising atmospheric concentrations of GHGs, emissions continue to increase at a faster pace than previously anticipated.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Yeah, but hold on, there's actually a silver lining, right? Like, on one front, we've actually exceeded expectations in the fight against climate change.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but hold on, there's actually a silver lining, right? Like, on one front, we've actually exceeded expectations in the fight against climate change.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On one front, however, progress in the fight against climate change has exceeded expectations.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, really? Tell me more, because I feel like I only hear the bad stuff sometimes.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, really? Tell me more, because I feel like I only hear the bad stuff sometimes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, think about it. The global shift to EVs, the accelerated adoption of solar and wind power... demand for renewables is just, it's soaring, especially in the US and EU.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, think about it. The global shift to E Vs, the accelerated adoption of solar and wind power... demand for renewables is just, it's soaring, especially in the U S and E U.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Amid the global shift from internal combustion engines to electric vehicles (EVs) and the accelerated adoption of solar and wind power, demand for renewable energy is rapidly increasing in the US and the European Union.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and that's partly thanks to, like, the Inflation Reduction Act here in the US, right? And, uh, I guess, cheaper imports?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and that's partly thanks to, like, the Inflation Reduction Act here in the U S, right? And, uh, I guess, cheaper imports?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the US, this can be attributed in part to the clean-energy subsidies included in President Joe Bidens Inflation Reduction Act and, more significantly, to low-cost Chinese imports.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! Big declines in the real prices of solar panels, wind turbines, batteries, EVs. A lot of that, honestly, has been fueled by low-cost Chinese imports.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! Big declines in the real prices of solar panels, wind turbines, batteries, E versus A lot of that, honestly, has been fueled by low-cost Chinese imports.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This increased demand has been fueled by significant declines in the real prices of solar panels, wind turbines, batteries, and EVs. In the US, this can be attributed in part to the clean-energy subsidies included in President Joe Bidens Inflation Reduction Act and, more significantly, to low-cost Chinese imports.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so far, so good. We're getting cheaper clean tech, demand is up, things are moving. But there's a big "but" coming, isn't there?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so far, so good. We're getting cheaper clean tech, demand is up, things are moving. But there's a big but coming, isn't there?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, there absolutely is. Alarmingly, new tariffs imposed by the US and the EU on these very things – solar panels, EVs, other equipment – they're threatening to derail all this progress.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, there absolutely is. Alarmingly, new tariffs imposed by the U S and the E U on these very things - solar panels, E Vs, other equipment - they're threatening to derail all this progress.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Alarmingly, new tariffs imposed by the US and the EU on imports of solar panels, EVs, and other equipment, threaten to derail this progress.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, we're talking about a massive investment, right? Like, the global electricity sector alone needs $3.5 trillion annually between 2021 and 2050. Western countries are demanding China pay its fair share, but then we're... slapping tariffs on them. It seems a bit, uh, contradictory.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, we're talking about a massive investment, right? Like, the global electricity sector alone needs three point five trillion dollars annually between twenty twenty one and twenty fifty. Western countries are demanding China pay its fair share, but then we're... slapping tariffs on them. It seems a bit, uh, contradictory.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While estimating the cost of the clean-energy transition is a difficult task, even conceptually, the global electricity sector alone is projected to require $3.5 trillion in capital investment annually between 2021 and 2050. Western countries have demanded that China pay its fair share of these costs, but their own trade policies are starkly at odds with their objectives.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It totally is! The US, for example, under Biden, just slapped a 100% tariff on Chinese EVs. And new levies on solar cells, lithium-ion batteries. The EU is doing similar things, 31% average tariffs on Chinese EVs.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It totally is! The U S, for example, under Biden, just slapped a one hundred percent tariff on Chinese E versus And new levies on solar cells, lithium-ion batteries. The E U is doing similar things, thirty one percent average tariffs on Chinese E versus
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In May, the Biden administration imposed a 100% tariff on Chinese EVs, along with new levies on a range of other Chinese goods, including solar cells and lithium-ion batteries. ... The new EU tariffs, while not prohibitive, average 31%, which is substantially higher than the duties on conventional car imports from other trading partners.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And the stated reason for this, I mean, is to protect American workers and domestic industries. But doesn't that risk undermining our *own* climate agenda? Like, the goal for 100% renewables by 2035, or 50% EV sales by 2030?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the stated reason for this, I mean, is to protect American workers and domestic industries. But doesn't that risk undermining our own climate agenda? Like, the goal for one hundred percent renewables by twenty thirty five, or fifty percent E V sales by twenty thirty?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: These measures aim to protect American workers and critical domestic industries. But they risk undermining the administrations climate agenda, particularly its efforts to raise the share of renewables to 100% of US electricity by 2035 and the share of EVs to 50% of new car sales by 2030.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! It makes it more expensive, you know? And this isn't a new thing. Targeting Chinese cleantech goes back a decade, accelerated under Trump, and now, like you said, under Biden. It's even pushed some Chinese manufacturers to Southeast Asia, and now the US is investigating *them* too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! It makes it more expensive, you know? And this isn't a new thing. Targeting Chinese cleantech goes back a decade, accelerated under Trump, and now, like you said, under Biden. It's even pushed some Chinese manufacturers to Southeast Asia, and now the U S is investigating them too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Although the disproportionate targeting of cleantech imports from China dates back more than a decade, the trend accelerated significantly under former US President Donald Trump and has continued under Biden. In response to Western tariffs, some Chinese manufacturers have moved to Southeast Asia in recent years. Earlier this month, the US International Trade Commission decided to investigate claims by American solar-cell companies seeking to impose countervailing and anti-dumping duties on Southeast Asian manufacturers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So, on one hand, we want cheap clean energy to fight climate change. On the other hand, we're saying, "No, not *that* cheap clean energy, because it's from China and they subsidize it."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. So, on one hand, we want cheap clean energy to fight climate change. On the other hand, we're saying, No, not that cheap clean energy, because it's from China and they subsidize it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To be sure, while historically low labor costs and economies of scale have helped reduce the price of Chinese solar panels and EVs, generous government subsidies often in the form of cheap credit have also played a significant role.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and while China *does* subsidize its industry, the question is, how does blocking these low-cost imports actually benefit US and EU workers and consumers? I mean, it could lead to job losses in solar installation, for instance, which relies on affordable equipment.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and while China does subsidize its industry, the question is, how does blocking these low-cost imports actually benefit U S and E U workers and consumers? I mean, it could lead to job losses in solar installation, for instance, which relies on affordable equipment.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Although US tariffs may help create jobs in the solar-panel industry, those would be offset by job losses in the solar-energy installation sector, which relies on low-cost equipment.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And, uh, let's not forget the bigger picture. If we put tariffs on China, they're probably going to retaliate, which means job losses in our export sectors.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And, uh, let's not forget the bigger picture. If we put tariffs on China, they're probably going to retaliate, which means job losses in our export sectors.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Meanwhile, many export jobs would be cut when China and other countries inevitably retaliate against Western restrictions.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right. Plus, with inflation being a huge concern right now, especially here in the US, removing tariffs could actually lower energy and transportation prices. It seems like a pretty straightforward way to, you know, help fight inflation *and* the climate crisis.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. Plus, with inflation being a huge concern right now, especially here in the U S, removing tariffs could actually lower energy and transportation prices. It seems like a pretty straightforward way to, you know, help fight inflation and the climate crisis.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With US unemployment at 4%, policymakers and voters are currently more concerned about inflation than jobs. Removing tariffs is the surest way for Western governments to lower energy and transportation prices, thereby reducing inflation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, essentially, we're shooting ourselves in the foot by making the clean energy transition more expensive, all in the name of, uh, protecting workers, when in reality, it might actually hurt us more in the long run.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, essentially, we're shooting ourselves in the foot by making the clean energy transition more expensive, all in the name of, uh, protecting workers, when in reality, it might actually hurt us more in the long run.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. It's a classic example of how international trade could actually lower the costs of this massive transition, if we just, you know, embraced it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. It's a classic example of how international trade could actually lower the costs of this massive transition, if we just, you know, embraced it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This is yet another example of how international trade could lower the costs of the clean-energy transition if we were to embrace it.
